title: 108_s3007
content:
The Act may be cited as the "National Park Anniversaries-Great American Spaces Commemorative Coin Act". The National Park Foundation is the nonprofit partner of America's National Parks, raising funds and increasing public awareness. The National Park Service was established in 1916 to preserve scenic parks like Grand Canyon and historical sites like the Lincoln Memorial. Theodore Roosevelt emphasized the importance of defending these parks. Theodore Roosevelt emphasized the importance of leaving the land better for future generations. Parks like Grand Canyon and Devil's Tower, established under his presidency, embody this ideal. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS.

The Secretary of the Treasury shall mint and issue $1 silver coins for National Parks, each weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, and containing 90% silver and 10% copper. The coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of the coins minted under this Act will be emblematic of the National Park being commemorated, with inscriptions including the coin's value, minting year, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and the National Parks Foundation. The National Parks Foundation and Citizens Advisory Committee review the design of coins minted under this Act. Only one US Mint facility can strike each quality of coin. Specific National Parks, years of commemoration, and anniversaries are designated for the coins. In 2007, Devils Tower National Monument celebrated its 100th anniversary. In 2008, Grand Canyon National Park marked its 100th anniversary. Glacier National Park celebrated its 100th anniversary in 2010. Lincoln Memorial reached its 100th anniversary in 2011. Yosemite National Park celebrated its 150th anniversary in 2014. Rocky Mountain National Park marked its 100th anniversary in 2015. The National Park Service celebrated its 100th anniversary in 2016. Denali National Park reached its 100th anniversary in 2017. Acadia National Park celebrated its 100th anniversary in 2018. In 2019, Zion National Park celebrated its 100th anniversary. In 2020, Gettysburg National Military Park marked its 125th anniversary. The Act specifies that coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, starting from January 1 of the year of issuance. Minting authority ends on December 31 of the same year. Sales of coins can begin before the issuance date. The Secretary will sell coins at face value plus design and issuance costs. Bulk sales will be discounted, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. Coins can be sold individually or as sets. Surcharges are also specified in the Act. The Act requires a $10 surcharge per coin sold, with the proceeds to be distributed to the National Park Foundation for support of all National Parks. The Foundation is subject to audit requirements. SEC. 8. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Payment for coins requires full payment, security, or a guarantee from a depository institution.
